newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's labour union wants wage hike for economy.
newsitem.headline: Japan's labour union wants wage hike for economy.

text.p: The central group representing Japan's labour unions said on Wednesday it would demand an average wage hike of 13,000 yen per month in the coming annual negotiations.
Japanese Trade Union Confederation (Rengo) president Jinnosuke Ashida told a seminar that the wage increase was needed to boost the economy by expanding domestic demand.
"Our research arm said a self-sustainable economic recovery can be achieved by a wage hike," he said. "We will demand this and will fight for this target."
In Japan, labour and management hold a "shunto" spring labour offensive from February to March to set wages for the coming business year starting April 1.
This year's spring labuor offensive is expected to reach its climax on March 18 and 19 when most major unions will seek replies from their management, Ashida said.
Rengo's targeted wage increase is the same as last year's because the economy is still in the doldrums.
Ashida also said that Rengo would continue to urge the government to continue the two trillion yen special income tax cuts despite the government's decision to end the tax cuts from January 1997.

Separately, an official at the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations (Nikkeiren) said that management will oppose a wage increase because productivity has not been improving at a time of slow economic recovery.

The priorities are to ensure job security in the labour market and to improve productivity and cut prices, instead of increasing salaries, the official quoted a report approved by Nikkeiren's general meeting last month as saying.
